blocks.name: cqp
blocks.content: The set of ` p ` -adic rational numbers.

blocks.name: cqpOLD
blocks.content: The set of ` p ` -adic rational numbers. (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: czp
blocks.content: The set of ` p ` -adic integers. (Not to be confused with ~ czn .)

blocks.name: cqpa
blocks.content: Algebraic completion of the ` p ` -adic rational numbers.

blocks.name: df-zrng
blocks.content: Define the subring of integral elements in a ring. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)

blocks.name: df-gf
blocks.content: Define the Galois finite field of order ` p ^ n ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-gf(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cgf, cmpo(s0, s1, cprime, cn, csb(s2, cfv(czn, cv(s0)), cfv(c1st, co(cv(s2), csf, csn(csb(s3, cfv(cpl1, cv(s2)), csb(s4, cfv(cv1, cv(s2)), co(co(co(cv(s0), cexp, cv(s1)), cfv(cmg, cfv(cmgp, cv(s3))), cv(s4)), cfv(csg, cv(s3)), cv(s4))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-gf(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ GF =(s0 ‚àà Prime, s1 ‚àà ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶[(Z/nZ ` s0)/ s2](1st `(s2[splitFld]{[(Poly1 ` s2)/ s3][(var1 ` s2)/ s4](((s0[^]s1)[(.g `(mulGrp ` s3))]s4)[(-g ` s3)]s4)})))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
}

blocks.name: df-gfoo
blocks.content: Define the Galois field of order ` p ^ +oo ` , as a direct limit of the Galois finite fields. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-gfoo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cgfo, cmpt(s0, cprime, csb(s1, cfv(czn, cv(s0)), co(cv(s1), cpsl, cmpt(s2, cn, csn(csb(s3, cfv(cpl1, cv(s1)), csb(s4, cfv(cv1, cv(s1)), co(co(co(cv(s0), cexp, cv(s2)), cfv(cmg, cfv(cmgp, cv(s3))), cv(s4)), cfv(csg, cv(s3)), cv(s4))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-gfoo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ GF_oo =(s0 ‚àà Prime ‚Ü¶[(Z/nZ ` s0)/ s1](s1[polySplitLim](s2 ‚àà ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ {[(Poly1 ` s1)/ s3][(var1 ` s1)/ s4](((s0[^]s2)[(.g `(mulGrp ` s3))]s4)[(-g ` s3)]s4)})))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
}

blocks.name: df-eqp
blocks.content: Define an equivalence relation on ` ZZ ` -indexed sequences of integers such that two sequences are equivalent iff the difference is equivalent to zero, and a sequence is equivalent to zero iff the sum ` sum_ k <_ n f ( k ) ( p ^ k ) ` is a multiple of ` p ^ ( n + 1 ) ` for every ` n ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-eqp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(ceqp, cmpt(s0, cprime, copab(s1, s2, wa(wss(cpr(cv(s1), cv(s2)), co(cz, cmap, cz)), wral(s3, cz, wcel(csu(s4, cfv(cuz, cneg(cv(s3))), co(co(cfv(cv(s1), cneg(cv(s4))), cmin, cfv(cv(s2), cneg(cv(s4)))), cdiv, co(cv(s0), cexp, co(cv(s4), caddc, co(cv(s3), caddc, nat1))))), cz))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-eqp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ ~Qp =(s0 ‚àà Prime ‚Ü¶ { < s1, s2 > |({ s1, s2 } ‚äÜ(‚Ñ§[‚Ü¶]‚Ñ§)‚àß ‚àÄ(s3 ‚àà ‚Ñ§, sum(s4 ‚àà(‚Ñ§‚â• ` -u(s3)),(((s1 ` -u(s4))[-](s2 ` -u(s4)))[√∑](s0[^](s4[+](s3[+]1)))))‚àà ‚Ñ§))})
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
}

blocks.name: df-rqp
blocks.content: There is a unique element of ` ( ZZ ^m ( 0 ... ( p - 1 ) ) ) ` ` ~Qp ` -equivalent to any element of ` ( ZZ ^m ZZ ) ` , if the sequences are zero for sufficiently large negative values; this function selects that element. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-rqp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(crqp, cmpt(s0, cprime, cin(ceqp, csb(s3, crab(s1, co(cz, cmap, cz), wrex(s2, crn(cuz), wss(cima(ccnv(cv(s1)), cdif(cz, csn(nat0))), cv(s2)))), cxp(cv(s3), cin(cv(s3), co(cz, cmap, co(nat0, cfz, co(cv(s0), cmin, nat1)))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-rqp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ‚ä¢ /Qp =(s0 ‚àà Prime ‚Ü¶(~Qp ‚ãÇ[{ s1 ‚àà(‚Ñ§[‚Ü¶]‚Ñ§)| ‚àÉ(s2 ‚àà ran(‚Ñ§‚â•),(`' s1 "(‚Ñ§ \ { 0 }))‚äÜ s2)} / s3](s3 √ó(s3 ‚ãÇ(‚Ñ§[‚Ü¶](0[...](s0[-]1)))))))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
}

blocks.name: df-qp
blocks.content: Define the ` p ` -adic completion of the rational numbers, as a normed field structure with a total order (that is not compatible with the operations). (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.) (Revised by AV, 10-Oct-2021.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-qp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, setvar s6, setvar s7) {
  |- wceq(cqp, cmpt(s0, cprime, csb(s3, crab(s1, co(cz, cmap, co(nat0, cfz, co(cv(s0), cmin, nat1))), wrex(s2, crn(cuz), wss(cima(ccnv(cv(s1)), cdif(cz, csn(nat0))), cv(s2)))), co(cun(ctp(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s3)), cop(cfv(cplusg, cnx), cmpo(s4, s5, cv(s3), cv(s3), cfv(cfv(crqp, cv(s0)), co(cv(s4), cof(caddc), cv(s5))))), cop(cfv(cmulr, cnx), cmpo(s4, s5, cv(s3), cv(s3), cfv(cfv(crqp, cv(s0)), cmpt(s6, cz, csu(s7, cz, co(cfv(cv(s4), cv(s7)), cmul, cfv(cv(s5), co(cv(s6), cmin, cv(s7)))))))))), csn(cop(cfv(cple, cnx), copab(s4, s5, wa(wss(cpr(cv(s4), cv(s5)), cv(s3)), wbr(csu(s7, cz, co(cfv(cv(s4), cneg(cv(s7))), cmul, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, nat1), cexp, cneg(cv(s7))))), clt, csu(s7, cz, co(cfv(cv(s5), cneg(cv(s7))), cmul, co(co(cv(s0), caddc, nat1), cexp, cneg(cv(s7))))))))))), ctng, cmpt(s4, cv(s3), cif(nat0, co(cv(s0), cexp, cneg(cinf(cima(ccnv(cv(s4)), cdif(cz, csn(nat0))), cr, clt))), wceq(cv(s4), cxp(cz, csn(nat0)))))))))
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s3, s7)
  -| diffss(s3, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s4, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s4, s7)
  -| diffss(s4, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s5)
  -| diffss(s5, s7)
  -| diffss(s5, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s5)
  -| diffss(s2, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s7)
  -| diffss(s1, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s6, s7)
  -| diffss(s0, s7)
  -| diffss(s2, s7)
  -| diffss(s0, s6)
  -| diffss(s2, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
}

blocks.name: df-zp
blocks.content: Define the ` p ` -adic integers, as a subset of the ` p ` -adic rationals. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)

blocks.name: df-qpa
blocks.content: Define the completion of the ` p ` -adic rationals. Here we simply define it as the splitting field of a dense sequence of polynomials (using as the ` n ` -th set the collection of polynomials with degree less than ` n ` and with coefficients ` < ( p ^ n ) ` ). Krasner's lemma will then show that all monic polynomials have splitting fields isomorphic to a sufficiently close Eisenstein polynomial from the list, and unramified extensions are generated by the polynomial ` x ^ ( p ^ n ) - x ` , which is in the list. Thus, every finite extension of ` Qp ` is a subfield of this field extension, so it is algebraically closed. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-qpa(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cqpa, cmpt(s0, cprime, csb(s1, cfv(cqp, cv(s0)), co(cv(s1), cpsl, cmpt(s2, cn, crab(s3, cfv(cpl1, cv(s1)), wa(wbr(co(cv(s1), cdg1, cv(s3)), cle, cv(s2)), wral(s4, crn(cfv(cco1, cv(s3))), wss(cima(ccnv(cv(s4)), cdif(cz, csn(nat0))), co(nat0, cfz, cv(s2)))))))))))
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-qpa(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ _Qp =(s0 ‚àà Prime ‚Ü¶[(Qp ` s0)/ s1](s1[polySplitLim](s2 ‚àà ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ { s3 ‚àà(Poly1 ` s1)|((s1[deg1]s3)[‚â§]s2 ‚àß ‚àÄ(s4 ‚àà ran((coe1 ` s3)),(`' s4 "(‚Ñ§ \ { 0 }))‚äÜ(0[...]s2)))})))
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
}

blocks.name: df-cp
blocks.content: Define the metric completion of the algebraic completion of the ` p ` -adic rationals. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Dec-2014.)
